page.title: 01GENERAL DESCRIPTION
page.content:
This, the north-eastern corner of Jersey, is largely unknown by the hordes of tourists who annually invade the Island, except for the breakwater at{St. Catherine's Bay,}part of a grand naval harbour which was never completed.
The coastline of cliffs indented with small rocky bays is largely made up of{Rozel Conglomerate,}a sedimentary rock full of pebbles, which was formed by deposition from flash floods in a mountainous desert.
Inland the area is wholly devoted to farming, both dairy and arable. The whole lies in the{Parish of St.Martin, which also administers a reef of rocks known as{Les Ecrehous,}about three miles to the north-east, on which is a small cluster of fishermen's huts.
